Personally, I think thereâ€™s a right way, and a wrong way to be an antagonistic player.   Iâ€™ve seen many other lets plays, and even experiments, thatâ€™ve had antagonistic players, and/or trolls, that I greatly enjoyed. They never took things too far, while still playing their role as antagonists.   This came off as mean spirited, and honestly a lot of the players seemed to be unhappy about this. It really seemed to ruin the fun for most of them.   It personally made me dislike the video, as it got extremely annoying. Like a rotten boss at your job that makes your life miserable.   I personally find it much more enjoyable to watch players having fun, and working together through hardships. Even if thereâ€™s a civil war, or conflict, itâ€™s not usually 1 player forcing others into it. Watching people *willingly* create chaos together is just much more enjoyable.

hello! here to talk about genshin, since 75% of the replies on the pinned comment are seriously delusional.  1: the community is not as bad as people make it out to be. you take one look at twitter and decide "yeah, this is the entire fandom!!!" twitter is literally THE HIVE of weirdos. a lot of the people that post NSFW of minors in the game, or just the characters in general, arent even fans of the game, and are just using the characters because they have a slight anime style to them. and about the racists and proshippers, nope, 70% of them are bait and are trying to make the community look worse than it is in reality. open your eyes.  2: "its a copy of BOTW!" fun fact, it really isnt. its easy to assume, considering a lot of the game mechanics have the same system, but genshin did get permission from the creators of BOTW to quote unquote "copy" them.  3: the company being "racist". im not going to deny, the company is very colorist. but, there are plenty of problematic companies out there, but thats not gonna stop anyone from enjoying a game. people saying that the game doesnt have a lot of diversity in skin color are correct, but its a fantasy game. its not supposed to be all about cluture and skin colors. EDIT: the game does actually have a lot of cultural aspects, such as weapon designs, character clothing, scenery, etc. you just dont pay attention to it and think that representation is only about skin color.  4: the unrealistic beauty standards. you may have noticed that most women in the game have body features that you may not like that much, but like... thats just what women look like. are you just gonna get mad because they have slightly bigger tits than avarage??? thats dumb. honorable mention! the reason to why none of them are chubby, is pretty obvious. you can see clearly in game that the characters move around a lot, so obviously theyre gonna lose weight.  5: the "boring" gameplay. its not a game for everyone, i can agree with that 100%. but a lot of people dont even give valid reasons to why they think the game is boring. some people play for like 2 minutes and then complain that theres nothing to do. well yeah??? you just started. what do you expect? the playstyle and exploration mechanisms are very fun once you start to understand them more, you just dont give the game a chance to actually show any of the mechanics.  thank you for coming to my ted talk. if you have any further questions or complants, im more than happy to explain to you.

Jungle king made s really good points and both wise and strange decisions. Taking away a big mouth yet powerless leader is a great point, that simulation was about last nation surviving so peace was never an option. Killing him was ruthless, tho necessary, you don't need a civil war going on while you're at war. Blitzkrieg against weakest participants was the right move, not a single junglian dead, neat. But the fact that they couldn't kill all artics made everything shatter. First of all they should have regrouped, advanced their gear even more, they knew the coordinates of deserts, and could sneak somewhere getting everyone full armor and such, but they decided to lean on individual, which was a bad idea. That strong unit should have been used as in previous fight, covered by tons of smaller units, not acting like a hero. Good strategy in their case may be start a partisan war, taking down deserts one by one, maybe even in a few days. Another option is to make a second big battle, where they had all chances. Using various factors such as mobs, explosions, maybe even lava or something. Good move from arctitcs to kill a jungle traitor, they couldn't know what was on his mind, tho seemingly he may not have betrayed them. And deserts just didn't do anything, having a full force, not fatigued by war they just could face the attack

It's funny how everyone just automatically label the person with the crown as the leader. It's not like they'd lose the game if the person with the crown is killed. If they were clever, they'd make the person with the crown a general instead given the health and strength boost. Ize will be the military general with his good gears while Starkiller will be in charge of logistics due to his popularity. As for the leader, it should go to someone who wants to achieve the goal. Not someone who wants to rule.  Honestly, Ize and Starkiller is a reflection of modern day politicians. One is an egotistic person who think they should rule because they believe themselves to be stronger. The other is an outspoken person who think the person with the most favor should rule. This isn't a body building contest nor is it a popularity contest. The goal is to survival and defeat the other teams. Something that both Ize and Starkiller is neither capable of doing.

Ize is like putin
The Jungle Leader used the element of surprise considerably well - however he lacked the competence to organise his people and instil discipline - many Jungle people strayed off and were killed alone. He needed to delegate and spread responsibility - not enough two-way communication. The impetus of his push on the Desert people dissipated rapidly with the lack of discipline, organisation and effective communication.   The Desert and Tundra people made one big mistake - their settlements lacked a perimeter - by this I mean no watchmen to catch incoming movements early - this gave them literally no time whatsoever to organise themselves and so they lost many to early routing.   The Tundra people could have repelled the initial Jungle assault even when they numbered only 10 by 'defeating in detail'. A famous tactic employed by Napoleon, concentrate your forces and engage a scattered enemy so that in every engagement you locally have the greater numbers. With good leadership this could have been done incredibly effectively.

itâ€™s so strange how this video recreates the story of harold godwinson without even meaning to ?  basically harold godwinson was a powerful soldier who was named king (ize) after the former king died (star killer) , and then he caught wind of other armies coming to england so he went out of his way to ambush them first. he forced peasants with no fighting experience to join the army which lead to famine and the vikings in the north of england (in this case the arctic kingdom) . the duke of normandy then led his army to england and they just chilled out while they waited for the anglo saxons to come to them (the desert kingdomâ€™s actions) and because of haroldâ€™s pompous attitudes and beliefs that he was the best warrior, he led his army to charge the normans who were already prepared, and he died :) the normans then took control of england .  whatâ€™s weird is that even the part where the jungle army came from over the mountain is similar to how the saxons attacked the normans from the top of the hill in the battle of hastings . itâ€™s so cool how history repeats itself in subtle ways

Jungle obviously was not, as despite their impressive military might they had a leader who was arrogant and selfish. Desert was the only Kingdom that had true uniformity. They had an elected King who accepted the responsibility, had the kindness and tact to accept the Arctic refugees but also be wary of them, meaning their betrayal wouldnâ€™t be as bad, and they had both the military strength to oppose the Jungle as well as the cunning to overwhelm their blitzkrieg style of combat. What is absolutely hilarious about this entire situation is that the Jungle was by far the most defensible position. They were on an isolated island with an open view of almost any attacking force, mining beneath them would be pretty difficult, and outside the island the Jungle would be easily the hardest biome to cross, it retained higher numbers of mobs than either desert or snow biome would have due to the trees.  In fact the main downfall of the jungle was that there was no long term strategy for actual invasion, the entire plan was essentially, just spend the entire time fighting, but there was clearly no rally point, not thoughts on defending their own village and the advantage of surprise against the snow biome put everyone at risk, in fact the plan which seemed to be straightforward makes no real sense, because the advantage of surprise is only viable if no one knows whats going on. And in a battle where the goal is elimination an all out attack wouldn't make sense, instead after the Snow People were defeated they should have either set up in a defensible position within that village or retreated, since combined numbers of Snow + Desert gave them a severe advantage over the jungle village wouldn't have had the disadvantage of being surprised if they had established a fortified position, and could have won.

Ngl I was happy Ize failed. Aside from being an overall asshole, he was a dictator, a horrible leader and a bad strategist.
Ize was supposed to be a talented aide to Starkiller who had the charisma to unite everyone. Instead he let his luck and expertise go to his ego.
The jungle kingdom had great military strategy but a divided populace. The arctic kingdom had  good military strategy and a populace that at least wasnâ€™t out to kill each other.   But in the end, the desert kingdom with their desert power, was extremely united in a common purpose. Their overall military strength was only decent, but they had great tactical commanders and a solid society that prioritized the right things and shared resources between the rich and the poor.   Funny enough, this touches on real world concepts. If, like the JK, your nation is ruled by a tyrant, it will have some success militarily before succumbing to the weaknesses inherent in tyranny. If, like the AK, your nation has no internal strife but also doesnâ€™t have unity and strong leadership, it will eventually succumb to the will of a tyrant. However, if your nation has competent selfless leaders and a populace dedicated to the betterment of all through the efforts of all, as well as a strong economy and a standing military, like the DK; then your nation will prosper and be able to survive exterior threats.   The even funnier thing, is that the majority of the worldâ€™s countries (including the 5 permanent members of the UN Security Council) still only fall into the JK and AK categories. The few countries that are in the DK category are well known, but Iâ€™ll give you some hints: - free universal healthcare  - free college education  - required 2yr military training for all citizens  - criminal justice system that actually reforms criminals - higher standards of living - extremely low poverty and crime rates - treats drug abuse as a sickness rather than a crime - creates some of the worldâ€™s best technologies

Ize was way too arrogant and self-centred to be leader. Even though he said he wanted to be King to help them win, in reality he wanted to be king for himself. It's easy to see; he abandoned the group right from the start in order to get better gear for HIMSELF, and then refused to share anything, even the enchanting table which giving to them in no way harmed himself, until he realised it would help his bid for leadership. Then instead of trying to help them do anything like gather food or other resources, he dragged them into what would've been a civil war if STARKILLER hadn't been the one to step down - which, ironically, marked him as the superior leader as he thought of the Jungle Team above himself and his own glory. Then Ize lead them almost immediately into war during a very dangerous time - this bet paid off, yes, but cost him a lot of people that could have possibly turned the tide. At no point, either, did he express any kind of remorse or worry over the death of his people. Then instead of fighting with his Army, he went after people on his own - was he luring away the Desert's best fighters? Maybe. It seemed to me more like he was trying to take them on himself to make himself look cool. Eventually, this decision to leave his army alone got both him and his army killed, in a beautiful display of what happens when you bite off more than you can chew.  Thanks, Ize, for being the best worst leader there was. It certainly was entertaining :D

i hate artic sooo much and desert
Ize aggressive strategy was good, he took both other nations completely by surprise seizing the advantage. He was ultimately just too impatient. He could've taken the 10 minutes necessary to formulate a plan in order to safely travel during the blood moon. That would have been at least 5 soldiers that could've turned the tides in the PvP fights. After his success against the Arctic army he should've paused and acknowledged the fact that they were outnumbered. They had vastly superior gear. They should've again just taken ten minutes to make a plan, they had a perfect opportunity for a real ambush. Nobody expected their bloodthirsty blitzkrieg on the arctic nation, the last thing they'd expect after that was for the madlads to sprint straight there without going back for resupply. If they had just taken a breath and taken 5 or 10 minutes to talk out an actual plan they could've still maintained the element of surprise, and also implemented a real tactical plan, perhaps utilizing their tnt they could've buried clusters of tnt under the sand, each with a designated sapper wielding a flint and steel and each with their own escape tunnel filled with water. Then they could've utilized their heavily geared elites by sending them forward to engage the desert forces, picking off the weaker members and forcing their more elite players to pursue. Intentionally lure them over the tnt that has been placed just beneath the surface of the sand. Detonate it and boom the elite core of the desert army could've been annihilated instantly. Then the moment the tnt goes off the remainder of the jungle forces, who had been purposely spread out and crouching behind cover to remain undetected, could've charged to mop up the remaining desert forces while they were disoriented and confused from the explosion. Any weaker players could have taken up sniper positions with enchanted bows to try and pick off any stragglers trying to escape. That literally took me 5 minutes to come up with by myself lol. Like damn,  "run dat wai and keel stoof!!" Isn't a plan lol

Ize was the perfect villain with a perfect story. An ambitious man who became a powerful warrior. If only he had become Starkiller's military general, perhaps they could have won. Instead, his arrogance and greed compelled him to take over the civilization as a tyrannical warlord and seek world domination. The very thing that cause his rise to power resulted in his demise and the destruction of the jungle tribe. While rallying his soldiers, he condemned Starkiller's strategy,  of "sitting on the island until everyone else kills each other and they come and slaughter you like pigs", but that very same strategy ended up being the reason the democratic, and relatively peaceful desert tribe won in the end.

Next time add a population rising attribute so that after every X minutes, X amount of players get added and X amount of players get removed. Both with same rate as of real world.   Wikipedia says: UN, medium variant, 2019 rev. The average global birth rate was 18.1 births per 1,000 total population in 2021. The death rate was 7.7 per 1,000. The 2021 average of 18.1 births per 1,000 total population equates to approximately 4.3 births per second or about 259 births per minute for the world. And 7.7 is close to half of that so basically ~2.2 deaths per second....  Now go figure out how to accurately implement this in a minecraft simulation.

Someone is really biased against Among Us :p  Any, Ize is by far the worse of the three tyrannical players, alongside Clownpierce and Solev. He only wanted power for the sake of power, and he ignored how good leadership Star was doing. Once he got power, he displayed overall incompetence by not doing anything to boost his civs morale, which lead to frequent backstabs and going against one another. His political image didn't help him either as he would threaten to kill someone if he met them. His Military tactics was terrible, he had no unit cohesion with any of his group, And his use of intimidation tactics resulted in his troops being easy routed and killed. Everyone was apart from one another, which easily allowed the Desert Kingdom to group up and pick them off one by one. All Ize had as a "Leader" was Crazy charges with no other strategy behind them, it worked against the Artic because they were off guard, but once the desert kingdom was warned, this strategy was easily taken apart.  Ize is the perfect example of a sweaty player who takes everything too seriously and thinks brute force is the solution to everything.  Edit: Now that time has past, and newer civilization videos are popping up, I think I will take Solev off the list. Solev is a decent player depending on the map, if its a map with only one group to start, then he can become a decent leader; If its a multi nation map, then yea that's where his flaws start showing up. Harboring treacherous refugees and calling their parent nation "Tyrant", dispersing his military during political turmoil, have no watch towers alongside the coast to watch for invaders, etc. He's inexperienced when it comes to running a military.

25:05 ah yes caught off guard by a creeper gets killed by a phantom
It would've been interesting if one of the players could come up with some very good plans in advance to secure their nation and most importantly their people. The Arctic Nation for example, had that much opportunity. Despite their disadvantage of being located in a freezing cold terrain, it doesn't mean they cannot make better use of it. For example, the escape tunnel the general came up with could've been developped even greater. A better tunnel systems that linked between house to the dwarven fortress or to a bunker. And when the country's under attack for example, everyone would've been ready and they retreat in a well-mannered and organized way. This could have been a battle of attrition or a guerrilla warfare in a frozen area. In addition to the tunnel systems, I would've set up traps and ambushes under the snow or in the mountains, followed up with the scorched earth policy by burning down and detonate bombs in key areas in my territory or the village to slow down and kill the enemies without coming in contact with them. Or even crazier, carpet bomb the hell out of them (unless it's not allowed) General sUeP did his best as a military strategist, however it would've been better if both the Desert and Arctic nations made the best possible plans and countermeasures against the attackers. Because there will be always war and you cannot just win with conventional warfare.

I was rooting for jungle up until Star got his rights to live removed from the chat. It was then when I knew jungle was doomed to fail.  If you silence the competition who willingly stepped down and cooperated, you are looking at a government doing whatever it takes to accomplish something, which sometimes isn't wrong unless you throw others against whatever you may find just to satisfy some sort of overinflated ego. While winter's general (sounds cool that way) could have made a couple of smart choices along the way, I think it was a good ending for him, having at least avenged his people. Desert was the sleeping giant, the silent monster if you like. They minded their own business and played smart while jungle played hard. Both methods with their own merits, but maybe with a different leadership jungle would have made it. All in all, this was a sweet video and I liked that at least most people got what they deserved, both as in rewards and consequences.

If I were the jungle king, I'd create designated points for each class. this allows warriors to patrols the outskirts of the village, as well as the inside, and they will have the best armor because an invasion would be inevitable. In the case another village tries to invade, I'd tell all the farmers to get as far away as possible and send coordinates after 1 Minecraft day. that way, if the invasion succeeds, the miners and farmers can start over. During the blood moon, I'd have everyone inside  their houses and have them save as much food as possible for the 5 days. after the blood moon, I can send a single soldier, farmer, and miner to the opposing villages, and have them ask for refuge. if they are killed, I know the enemy is hostile against other villages. if not, I can send more and more soldiers to the village and form an alliance. little do that know, I plan on killing all of them, if need be. the other king and I will set up an invasion plan to another village. we will send half of our combined forces there, and wait for a response. we would need some soldiers in the village to keep watch. after the attack, assuming it is a success, the 2 remaining villages can live together in peace, until someone, sooner or later, decides to start a war...

Nice touch with the Genshin Impact fighting music! Such a fun video.
This was very great to watch. Well done to everyone ğŸ‘ If you want to read my opinionated analysis on the reasons for victory & failure u can Read below. Spoilers below:  All the civilizations did very well in building, strength, and teamwork. Arctic being the most creative, Jungle having the most strength & Desert having the best Team work mind. However,  Jungle's team made the unfortunate mistake in leadership. Strength comes a long way, but it's worth nothing without team work & a good leader & I'm sorry to say Ize was not a good leader. The difference between a good leader is one who uses the word "We" instead of "I". Once he was leader I sadly felt jungle would not succeed. Once they attacked Arctic they became the aggressors. Now because of the brutal surprise attack and ill prepared Artic troops, this cost Arctic the win with little fault of their own. However this forced the artic to have a small alliance with desert against a single foe.  With the alliance, the element of surprise gone, & the Teamwork of the desert, jungle was surely to lose a 2nd immediate assault. The Desert had a clear advantage with a strong team mind, home turf, knowledge of an attack & Arctic alliance. Jungle made the mistake of looking to one to do all the damage instead of strengthening everyone's ability as a whole & it was Ize who made the mistake to boast, thinking he could do it all, & thinking mostly of his own power instead of his team's. He was just in the wrong position, top soldier, general, or best of all military supplier would have probably been better, but based on his personality & aggressive need for power he ruined his chance to be a good leader for his team. Especially when his first reaction of difference of opinions is immediate execution. This story actually follows similar paths throughout history which I find very cool. As the saying goes those who fail to learn history is doomed to repeat it. so based on past historic events logically jungle was doomed to fail based on poor leadership. In summary Jungle failed due to leadership issues, Arctic's chance of winning was destroyed in a surprise attack, and all this gave Desert the tactical advantage to win as a Team. This was just my opinionated analysis with the small knowledge I have & everyone did well with what they had.   All in all very entertaining, hope everyone had fun, & great work to everyone involved. Keep up the hard work ğŸ‘.

I have a suggestion for the Civilisation game based off of the sid mires games.  I don't know if this is even possible.  But let me know what you think.   At the end of each session, before you close the server, you let people vote on which Tech to unlock.  Domestic animals don't spawn on the server unless Animal Husbandry is picked.  Iron, Gold, Dimond Etc Ore texture is replaced with stone. Technically you Can mine them, but they're practically invisible to the player until Iron workings, currency etc is unlocked.  Border expanse beyond the ocean is unlocked with the Navigation tech.  Buckets are got via Aquaduct tech. I can imagine them building the structure, then when You decide it's done, you add the water on top in a joyful moment before showering them with buckets.   Maybe even have secret unlocks.  For example. If the player base decides a leader, they unlock Democracy. Ironically, it removes the one man one vote rule and their chosen leader alone gets to decide what the new tech is.

The Jungle kingdom had everything to win: a strong leader, good gear, high team morale and most importantly a strong desire to achieve victory. However, they let that desire and power get into their heads because of a series of events and coincidences.  Let's start with their begining: They spawned with an area with abundant early-game resources like food and wood, and didn't have much trouble going trough the famine event, so they developed very quickly at the start and got ahead of the others.  Now to their first "leader" Starkiller: He was a key piece in unifying that whole region to make the most of their resources and to get them to do teamwork. You can think of him as a "parent" that was looking out for their child and doing the best for them.  Their second leader and first king Ize: He was a man with the true desire to win that game and went out of his way to make sure that would happen. He knew a friendly leader like Starkiller would make the cut, so he went against him. Now, that wasn't easy to do because of Star's popularity and how the people viewed him as wholesome, which is a very strong weapon to get people to agree with you. So, Ize's only option was to take the kingdom by force and forbidding other members of talking about Star, and that was made possible by the strong gear and allies he had.  The artic invasion: It started out roughly with people dying at the start and loyalty to Ize low, as some people viewed him as evil and a dictator. Although I still think the invasion was in no way off timing, since had he waited any longer, the Starkiller followers would have thrown him out of his position or at least caused unnecessary deaths. Ize managed to convince all of them (and it's important to note that he convinced *all* of them, because, had some not followed, trust would never be built in those that stayed behind, not to mention the invasion would probably never have succeeded that way) and then led them to what was (luckily) the all-time-high of the entire jungle civilization with the defeat of the artic people.  The downfall of the jungle civ: It started out with the king's rushed decision to invade the desert area. There were some reasons i believe caused this choice: The high team morale and newly-found trust in the king that would probably quicly fade and not have the same great effects in battle had they waited for longer. The new equipment and weapons they got from the raid since with their weaker army they still managed to beat a civilozation. The uncertainty of the next world event that could cause severe damage to their already low population. And lastly the idea that Ize and his people were the strongest and had already won the game, due to their previous big success. The reasons that led them to fail, however, are the following: The unorganized inventory of their available weapons and resources, the lack of a concrete plan of attack and strategy, the little knowledge available on the desert civ, the incomplete decimation of the artic people which allowed some of the defeated but still alive to join the desert civilization and the exceding trust and fear of warning their king, who could kill anyone that defied him.  Therefore, the jungle'uns were the most propense to win due to their strong headstart and passionate leader, however it took one rushed decision due to several reasons to make them fall. Thank you for coming to my TED-talk. (Also, I don't think i need to mention that this is merely my subjective appreciation of the events that happened in the video, and are in no way 100% guaranteed to be correct, comment down your own thoughts!)

Surprisingly, this is exactly how real life events takes place, each resembling a trait of a different form of power and human nature, the artic: passive with little strength but peaceful, the desert: a silent powerhouse with moderate power, and the jungle: a complete dictatorship with strong power.  Scary thing is the invasion of the jungle kingdom is what happens in real life as well, with a single leader taking power with strength and look to conquer other nations for more power, first ruling with only fear then uniting the people after a grand victory against another nation, but ultimately falling to a unified army with refugees from fallen nations. Three kingdoms built up. The jungle which was led by a charismatic leader who cared for his people. The Arctic that lived happily and enjoyed their time peacefully. The Desert who struggled to live but eventually strived and exceeded their environment, getting creative with their surroundings. All three kingdoms living peacefully until a greedy and ambitious person undermined and assassinated the charismatic and caring leader where he then forcefully took control of the jungle kingdom and ruled with am iron fist as a tyrant leader. Soon after leading his followers and the other reluctant kingdom to attack the peaceful arctic kingdom. Catching them off guard and slaughtering all but 5 of them. Among the 5 was the general of the Arctic kingdom that was the only one who managed to slaughter 2 of the jungles warriors I'm his escape. The refugees escaped the slaughter and made their way to the desert kingdom where they managed to join forces as the jungle kingdom started their invasion. A fierce fight erupted between the two sides with many of the desert warriors dying I'm the ensuing panic. Unbeknownst to them though. Two of the Arctic warriors who joined them have been staying to themselves and letting the others het slaughtered until they finally decided to help I'm the end to fight back. After many of their people had fallen, the desert kingdoms best warriors gathered together and teamed up to hunt down and kill the jungle kingdoms weakest warriors, successfully thinning out their numbers until the king was left all alone. As the king fought back with his strongest armor and weapons, A member of the desert kingdom who had died long ago only to resurrected by his dear friend as an undead, escaped from his captivity and rushed to the aid of comrades, fighting against the tyrant king. The king desperate to survive ran away from the warriors eventually finding aid with the general of the Arctic who had decided to betray the desert kingdom to aid the man who slaughtered his comrades. However it was all for naught. With the aid of their Undead comrade and their greatest warriors, they were able to cut down the Tyrant King and the Traitorous General. Eventually after the conflict was brought to an end they managed to capture the Jungle Kingdoms last surviving member. Bringing him to the throne room where he would be executed, the last remaining member decided to blow everyone up with him, I'm which he failed. After disarming the War Criminal, they had him executed by their Undead Comrade Abstrakt. Killing him and finally bringing peace to the land, free from the reign of a Tyrant King and free of bloodshed. The Desert Kingdom had won.

Ize was the only one in this simulation with a head on his shoulders. He was resourceful enough to attain leadership and assertive enough to demand respect. What the desert needed was a leader with direction, and as much as star was appreciated he didn't have the same conviction as ize. The plan to strike as the blood moon was ending was a tactical risk yes, but it was far from thoughtless. He managed to catch the enemy at a point they weren't ready to defend. The only reason casualties were suffered was due to half the group remaining behind, and ize even recognized that fault and fixed it! And the actual raid was so successful! He managed to eliminate 16 of their people without losing a single one during the active skirmish. And as a plus the desert kingdom thought it was a Civil War! After this point is when ize started getting cocky and stupid. He should have realized the plethora of tactical disadvantages he had since the enemy had greater numbers, resources, and preparation time. I would have opted for guerrilla tactics employing the usage of tnt against the desert to diminish their resource advantage. Instead ize made many fatal mistakes that cost him the war. Like seriously charging straight at the enemy through their territory after you've successfully won another biome! All in all his strategy was great until the dopamine and adrenaline got to his head and made him lose all brain function.

Already posted this on another video, but may as well spread my idea til someone gives it a shot: Interdimensional war.  Essentially, the three civilizations are residents of the overworld, nether, and end respectively, each with their own unique advantages and disadvantages as well as custom made maps to ensure they all had a fair chance at developing. After some time has passed, portals between dimensions would open up at undisclosed points on each map, and the civilizations would be allowed to cross over. Peace? War? It's all up to them to decide whether to align with their neighbors or become conquerors of worlds. As a bonus, perhaps their could be custom made, dimension specific bosses and mobs that come during specific events, making it not just a game of conquest, but survival.

It makes sense that the desert kingdom was the one that survived. First and foremost they were targeted second, after the ice kingdom, which gave them more time to prepare, but more importantly, they were more organized than either. They were forced out of neccessity to form a cohesive community that worked together and that's where their strength was. The Jungle kindgom was almost immediately blessed with everything they needed to start out with, and as such didn't need to form such an organized nation, eventually the prosperity lead to a power struggle that resulted in the war monger taking charge as they were all afraid of the common threat of a conflict with another nation. Then, in a complete 180 he lead them all to invade the ice kingdom immediately without hesitation, threatening to kill off his own people if they disobeyed him, or even questioned him. I believe the jungle kingdom's biggest mistake was their complete disregard for their people, treating all of them as disposable, and not taking the time to make a proper strategy for conquering the other kingdoms. This is highlighted when their king killed of one of their loyal subjects for being their opposition during the election. They may very well have survived if it werent for their ruthless killing of their own, but instead they became hyper millitaristic and self absorbed, destroying their own advantages simply in an attempt to grab power. Essentially, The Desert kingdom was forced to work together, making a cohesive nation that was formed to be efficient. The Ice kingdom was able to form a cohesive nation through similar struggle, but wound up not being efficient with their resources. The Jungle kingdom had no driving factor to make them become cohesive, it all just formed through the charasmatic leadership of StarKiller, and despite his glib, he was the only reason they formed one group to begin with, other than the impending doom of a potential clash with another nation. Ize started and ended through the subversion of his kingdom and it's resources, collecting all his resources for himself and used his power to dominate his competition, along side his rheteric, fast talking, and interruptions to force people to listen to him. The Jungle kingdom was advantaged in every way except for when it came down to being a community, which was its ultimate flaw. Frankly they should have been the ones who were successful, they had every opportunity to become more powerful together, insuring that materials went to where they were needed, and that proper defenses were constructed that would have made their jungle an impenetrable fortress with enough power to project it outwards in offensive attacks, but they wound up nearly starving to death in the easiest place to grow food and allowed one of their members to just fuck around getting materials only for themselves, which they painted as a good thing saying that they wouldn't have an enchantment table if they he didn't do that, which he then went on to invalidate as a benefit by not sharing his resources amongst his peers, being one of the few with full diamond armor, while some still had only iron. Ize took most the materials and power for himself while also expecting that all his people go on a suicide mission in order to be victorious, which of course, he would be one of the few to bask in their glory, being one of few left alive after the invasion of two other kingdoms. Of course, this is a game, I'm not taking criticizing any of these people seriously, but it is a very interesting insight into how civilizations form and what causes them to fall. It's kinda funny how quickly the Jungle Kingdom would have fallen if there were more nations, but to be fair they probably only considered that tactic because there weren't many other nations to deal with and they mopped the floor with the Ice Kingdom, leading them to believe that another suprise attack would yield similar results. If I were to suggest a new experiment, it would be to collect 1000 players, immediately spawn them evenly across advantageous locations around the world, naturally separated by land and sea, and let them naturally form into nations, perhaps with just a little bit of help by spawning them generally close together, and reminding them that other nations could wipe them out if they don't work together. Then it wouldn't be as likely to have one tribe essentially blitzkrieg another, or for a large proportion of a certain people to ditch everyone else in the pursuit of personal wealth. It would be a very difficult experiment to properly pull off though.

I think an important lesson we can learn from here is how Tyranny can manifest through the failure of the group to do something about it.  Jungle leader was ruthless and determined to get his goal via bloodshed and subjegation and because of that, the people couldn't naturally like him. Starkiller got power through cooperation and encouragement, so people generally liked him. However, Jungle Leader was determined to be on power whatever it took, and it was because of Starkiller's naivety that got him, and his kingdom destroyed.  Jungle Tyrant was very cocky and ruthless, and he used that ruthlessness to force his power upon people. And because the Jungle citizens didn't bother to even speak up against this Authoritarianism, they eventually fell down to collapse because of the leader's impulsive decisions to wage war on anyone.  This is a lesson that if you have a leader that you know you don't like, especially if it is a tough guy, it is important to speak up.  Also an important thing to note is that if the Jungle citizens strongly rallied to Starkiller's side, they would have had a better chance of surviving. But sadly, Jungle Tyrant took advantage of the people and Starkiller's naivety.  Jesus I never thought I would make a small essay about politics in Minecraft, but here we are.

Best idea for these things is to choose a kingdom where you can get or grow resources and also keep the people in the area working together. In this video it would be between desert and arctic, if there is leaves in the desert than that is the one you should choose. This will force people to work together because of the lack of resources but just enough to sustain a kingdom. Also, having certain people in control of areas would be good for a government. Having a king that cannot make decisions without the voice of other higher ranking people is q good idea so the king cannot have ultimate power. Having a person over control of resources, farming, and looting would be good with a king thats actions reflect off of their decisions. I would also study the other videos to see what we need to prepare for such as a bunker for the blood moons, having storage for food. Using a buddy system that swaps duos every now and then would reduce the risks of traitors and loosing resources. Having someone who is battle smart and how to prioritize things would be a must in a kingdom

I know it's supposed to be a lighthearted thing that's meant for fun but I couldn't stop analyzing all the horrible moves the jungle people made. They're successful ambush on the Arctic was complete luck. They're leader was a bumbling idiot who's thirst for blood cost him the win. If he had taken his time and evaluated the location of the final battle, he could have spread the Desert forces with a part of his army that were posing as a scouting patrol. Once the Desert gives chase, you come in behind them and sweep the weak and slow, because the strong warriors are up front, and the more vulnerable are left behind. Also, rushing in was a massive mistake. They had no idea what the terrain looked like.          Ize's decision to move during the Blood Moon was also a massive mistake, but it worked out. He weakened his army, even by a little bit, and in this game, numbers mean so much. In real life, technology is the main difference in winning battles. Look at two of the Ottoman Empires. The Safavids and Mughals were destroyed by cocky and arrogant leaders who forced their subjects to follow their foolish commands. They also were known as the Gunpowder Empire because they focused so much on gaining materials for war they fell behind in every other aspect, leading to their ultimate demise.          Ize did win my respect after conquering the Arctic Nation, because it worked out for him. If he'd been a bit less lucky, he would have been killed and ridiculed by his people. However, because it worked, the opposite effect occurred. That still doesn't take away that he acted like he knew what he was doing when really, he was as clueless as a blind rat in a maze.

Before I was with jungle but I did not like the king so I switch to destert
The jungle guys were convinced to join Ize's side easily because he made a few good points about how he will lead them to victory, but unlike Star, was yet to demonstrate any actual leadership skills or planning. He literally said it himself in the first war that they were kamikazing it, having literally no plan or strategy. The main reason they won was just because of the surprise element and better gear. Ize was all over the place most of the time and took crazy irrational decisions without thinking. Had they not been so aggressive, maybe the tides would have turned to their side considering that their homeland was already hard to travel through so anyone wanting to attack them would have had to deal with their natural defenses already present. Instead, Ize decided to get everyone to travel through those defenses instead, a very foolish move. Had the Arctic been more prepared, they would have won and Ize would have been demonstrated to be the fool that he was. Either way, it was incredibly satisfying to see him beg the general of the very people he fought against earlier for mercy, only to be defeated at the end. All in all, incredible work put in by Silver. You just earned a subscriber. Keep these kinds of videos coming. ;)

MEPs: Joint Efforts Several MEPs from different countries who attended the hearing strongly condemned the organ harvesting crimes committed by the CCP. They urged the European Parliament to take actions to curb organ harvesting and enhance organ transplant regulation as well as transparency.   MEP Maria Arena hosted the hearing.  Maria Arena, chair of the European Parliamentâ€™s Subcommittee on Human Rights, hosted the hearing. She said that auditing and transparency of organ harvesting are critical. This means deeper discussions are needed to explore how the European Parliament can influence China and follow up on this issue. This is not only limited to legal aspects but more options could also be considered at EU Plenary Meetings.   MEP Isabel Santos from Portugal  Isabel Santos, MEP from Portugal, is another member of the subcommittee on human rights. She said that data provided by Elliott did show organ harvesting was taking place in China on an industrial scale, which highlights the urgency of stopping the crime. The EU and other international organizations must join forces to stop the tragedy. She had heard about many cases in which Falun Gong practitioners were persecuted. And the victims are not limited to them.  Organ harvesting is truly a crime against humanity, explained Santos. Simply classifying it as a criminal activity is not enough. Those who benefit from organ harvesting or participate in it should also be viewed as criminals. This is probably the only way to stop it.   MEP MarÃ­a Soraya RodrÃ­guez Ramos from Spain  MarÃ­a Soraya RodrÃ­guez Ramos, MEP from Spain and another member of the subcommittee, said that organ harvesting in China has proven to be industrial-scale killing. She urged the EU to institute laws to prevent these organs from entering EU countries. She said this was an unprecedented crime and it is hard to believe it exists in the 21st century.  MEP Raphael Glucksmann from France agreed. He said this was one of the worst crimes we could see on earth.  EEAS Official: Human
